'''''Hericium erinaceus''''' (also called '''lion's mane mushroom''', '''monkey head mushroom''',<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ganofarm.com/monkey-head-mushroom/|title=Monkey Head Mushroom - GANOFARM|date=2017-04-10|work=GANOFARM|access-date=2018-01-04|language=en-US}}{{Dead link|date=April 2018|fix-attempted=no}}</ref> '''bearded tooth mushroom''', '''satyr's beard''', '''bearded hedgehog mushroom''', '''pom pom mushroom''', or '''bearded tooth fungus''') is an [[edible mushroom|edible]] and [[medicinal mushroom]] belonging to the [[tooth fungus]] group. Native to [[North America]], [[Europe]] and [[Asia]] it can be identified by its long spines (greater than 1 cm length), its appearance on hardwoods and its tendency to grow a single clump of dangling spines.<ref name=":0" /> ''Hericium erinaceus'' can be mistaken for other species of ''[[Hericium]]'', all popular edibles, which grow across the same range. In the wild, these mushrooms are common during late summer and fall on hardwoods, particularly [[American beech]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2018}}

==Chemistry==
''Hericium erinaceus'' contains a number of polysaccharides, such as [[Beta-glucan|B-glucan]], [[heteroglucan]]s, and [[heteroxylan]]s, as well as several [[cyathane]] derivative [[diterpenoid]]s known as [[hericenone]]s and [[erinacine]]s.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Mendel|title=Chemistry, Nutrition, and Health-Promoting Properties of Hericium erinaceus (Lion's Mane) Mushroom Fruiting Bodies and Mycelia and Their Bioactive Compounds|journal=J. Agric. Food Chem.|date=2015|doi=10.1021/acs.jafc.5b02914|volume=63|issue=32|pages=7108–7123|pmid=26244378}}</ref>
